title: ASX set to dip as big week of economic data looms
text:
In the US, Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Richard Clarida on Friday reiterated his stance that the central bank will "act as appropriate" to extend the US recovery and shield the economy from risks posed by geopolitical tensions and slowing global growth.

US economic data has grown increasingly gloomy, a development that could see the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates later this month, its third rate cut this year. Money markets are pricing in an 82 per cent chance of a rate cut at the October 30 meeting, Refinitiv data show.

There was also poor data out of China, with third-quarter growth slowing more than expected to its weakest pace in almost three decades as the bruising US trade war hit factory output. GDP rose 6.0 per cent year-on-year.

Today's agenda

Local: NZ credit card spending data September

Overseas data: UK Rightmove house prices October.

Market highlights

ASX futures down 14 points or -0.2% to 6602 near 9.47am Saturday AEDT

Advertisement

AUD +5% to 6857 US cents

On Wall St: Dow -0.9% S &P 500 -0.4% Nasdaq -0.8%

In New York: BHP -0.3% Rio +0.3% Atlassian -4.7%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.3% FTSE -0.4% CAC -0.6% DAX -0.2%

Spot gold -0.1% to $US1490.05 an ounce

Brent crude -0.9% to $US59.36 a barrel

US oil -0.3% to $US53.78 a barrel

Iron ore -0.8% to $US86.36 a tonne

Dalian iron ore +1.5% to 618 yuan

LME aluminium +0.6% to $US1738 a tonne

LME copper +1.2% to $US5806 a tonne

2-year yield: US 1.57% Australia 0.76%

5-year yield: US 1.57% Australia 0.79%

10-year yield: US 1.75% Australia 1.10% Germany -0.39%

10-year US/Australia yield gap: 65 basis points

From today's Financial Review

No panic on growth: Treasurer: Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has left Washington upbeat about challenges facing the global and domestic economies even as the IMF warned Australia must tackle tax reform and possibly tap the surplus to stimulate growth.

China starts new $10b Oakajee iron ore push: A Chinese state-owned entity will seek to revive a $9.7 billion mining rail and port project in Western Australia, in a move that could unlock the nation's next iron ore export province.

Boris Johnson set for one more one last heave to Brexit: The public want it. The EU wants it. Perhaps this week, a surly Parliament will put its numbers behind the PM's deal, writes Alexander Downer.

United States

The S &P 500 index closed out an uneven week of trading on Wall Street with its second straight weekly gain, even though stock indexes ended lower Friday.

Technology companies led the slide, which erased the major US indexes' gains from the day before. Communication services, industrials and health care stocks also fell.

Advertisement

Investors continued to focus on company earnings reports. They're searching for a clearer picture on the impact that the trade war between the US and China is having on corporate profits and the broader economy.

"To some extent, the bleeding's stopped, but now you need to figure out how healthy the patient is," said Willie Delwiche, investment strategist at Baird. "Earnings help with that, and economic data that we receive over the next couple of months will help with that."

Coca-Cola gained 1.8 per cent while Johnson & Johnson fell 6.2 per cent after the company said it is recalling a single lot of its baby powder because a test found trace amounts of asbestos in one bottle.

Europe

Investors are bracing for a frenzied trading day on Monday in the wake of an extraordinary weekend sitting of the UK parliament to push through Boris Johnson's Brexit deal.

Paul O'Connor, head of the UK-based Multi-Asset Team at Janus Henderson, said markets will be very sensitive to the margin of victory if the deal is approved in Parliament.

"It's a recipe for investors to execute only the most necessary moves in advance, before a possible 'manic Monday' in Saturday's wake," said City Index analyst Ken Odeluga.

Shares in London's UK-oriented businesses, such as housebuilders and retailers, could rocket to record highs if parliament approves the government's Brexit deal, investors say.

Advertisement

Parliament's approving the agreement would mean UK equities were no longer "uninvestable", according to brokerage Bernstein.

It has also moved to an "overweight" on European stocks, naming a Brexit resolution as a "catalyst to bring money back into European equities."

London-listed stocks ended a mixed week on a cautious note. InterContinental Hotels and oil stocks weighed on the FTSE 100, which closed 0.4 per cent lower. InterContinental shares fell 4.6 per cent on Friday after the Holiday Inn owner said lower business bookings in China and protests in Hong Kong had caused a drop in revenue.

UK-focussed mid-caps outperformed the blue-chip index and the European benchmark, which was dragged lower by a sharp fall in French carmaker Renault.

Allocations to UK equities dropped to record lows of 7.46 per cent last month, according to Copley Fund Research, which tracks more than 400 funds with $US800 billion in assets under management. That compares with an average of around 9.2 per cent before the referendum.

Asia

There were more disconcerting economic signals from China, which on Friday reported that its economy grew at its slowest pace in 26 years last quarter.

The 6 per cent growth pace China reported for July-September was worse than most economists were expecting, highlighting a global economy that is slowing. Domestically, Beijing is under significant pressure to head off job losses as a trade war with the US drags on.

Advertisement

Some of the latest data for September, such as investment and lending, showed improvement, but "pressure on economic activity should intensify in the coming months," Julian Evans-Pritchard of Capital Economics said in a commentary.

The Shanghai Composite index gave up early gains, sinking 1.3 per cent while Hong Kong's Hang Seng shed 0.5 per cent and the Kospi in South Korea skidded 0.8 per cent.

Currencies

The dollar fell sharply against the euro, with the European common currency bouncing on Brexit hopes. The euro was up 0.32 per cent at $US1.1158, a near two-month high. The pound was 0.45 per cent higher against the dollar at $US1.2946. The yuan held steady.

For the pound, 23 financial institutions polled by Reuters predicted on average that it would rise to almost $US1.34 - nearly 4 per cent above current levels. The most bullish predicted the currency would hit $US1.40.

"Investors are still short [sterling] and simply covering those shorts will push sterling above $US1.30," Normand added.

Commodities

The outlook for commodities in 2020 is expected to brighten, Capital Economics said in a note.

Advertisement

"We expect global economic growth to pick up over the course of the year, which in turn will prompt a rise in investor risk appetite. Both developments should give a boost to commodities demand," said Caroline Bain, chief commodities economist.

Industrial metals prices were volatile after China's economic growth slowed slightly more than expected to 6 per cent year-on-year in the third quarter, the weakest pace in almost three decades.

LME benchmark zinc rose 0.7 per cent to close at $US2457 a tonne, the highest since July 30. LME lead gave up 0.4 per cent to $US2181 a tonne, reversing direction after hitting $US2214.50, the highest since July last year.

Spot gold was little changed. "The $US1380-$US1400 range ought to be a solid bottom for gold and $US1480-$US1520 seems really to be the equilibrium," says Tai Wong, head of base and precious metals derivatives trading at BMO.

Gold discounts in India narrowed to a four-month low this week as some consumers took advantage of a modest dip in domestic prices to buy bullion ahead of Diwali. India's gold imports plunged 68 per cent year-on-year in September to their lowest in over three years as record domestic prices curbed retail buying.

The yield on benchmark 10-year Treasury notes fell to 1.7396 per cent compared with a US close of 1.755 per cent on Thursday.

Australian sharemarket

Profit expectations and dealmaking helped lift the Australian market in a week where Latitude's IPO collapsed and high-profile technology firms Afterpay and WiseTech came under significant selling pressure.

Advertisement

"The big news was the Latitude float," said Hugh Dive at Atlas Funds Management. Latitude abandoned its $3.2 billion initial public offering this week after failing to secure sufficient interest at $1.78 a share.

"It's probably good for the market," said Mr Dive. "There could have been some potential selling."

The S &P/ASX 200 index declined 34 points, or 0.5 per cent, to 6649.70 in Friday's session, paring weekly gains to 0.7 per cent.

Street Talk
description: Investors are in for another busy week of corporate earnings, including McDonald's on Tuesday, Boeing and Microsoft on Wednesday, and Amazon on Thursday.
